urn:contentItem:5W8B-GB31-JBHT-D2X0-00000-00WSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office Space2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:48:08ZLexisNexisWSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office SpaceLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there ladies, thank you so much. Happy Monday to you and good morning everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, thanks for joining us. It is Monday, April 23rd. Your top stories right now 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings on the driver seat on Wall Street this morning, Futures showing a decline at the start of trading today, down about 40 points on the Dow, down a fraction on the S&P, and down eight points on the NASDAQ. More than a third of the Dow and the S&P500 set to report their first quarter earnings this week. It is going to be a monster week for earnings.

Alphabet, the name to watch after the close tonight, it comes amid new concerns surrounding Google's data collection. Dan Niles Money Manager on Wall Street this weekend says he thinks Google will miss earnings estimates.

Markets tumbling on Friday, Apple dragged the Dow lower after analysts' reports suggested that smartphone sales could slow in the coming months. Also, Niles said Apple will miss. We are watching the fine market this morning, the 10-year yield creeping closer to three percent, take a look, up two basis points right now at 2.99 percent on the 10-year.

In Europe this morning, stocks looking like this, now we do have a lower opening there as well and lower trading this morning. CAC Quarante is down a fraction, CAC Quarante in Paris down a fraction as is the DAX Index in Germany, down a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight right across the board, the Hang Seng the biggest loser, down better than one-half of one percent in Hong Kong.

And a pair of former political outsiders inside the Oval Office, President Trump welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House today from trade to national security. We're taking a look at what's on the agenda for the two world leaders ahead of the state dinner tomorrow night.

Investigating the investigation, shocking new revelations on the start of the FBI probe into the Trump campaign. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes telling me yesterday about his findings, he explained on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE CHAIRMAN: We've long wanted to know what intelligence did you have that actually led to this investigation. So what we found now after the investigators have reviewed it is that in fact there was no intelligence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: No intelligence to launch that investigation. The very latest on the investigation coming up. Plus, another high note for the music industry, Chinese streaming giant Tencent reportedly planning to go public where the company is expected to list and that mammoth evaluation.

Plus, revving up their resume, Harley-Davidson offering an internship of a lifetime, how college students can get paid to ride coming up.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to talk about it, FOX BUsines Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO, Managing Partner, Mike Murphy along with Pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter. Good morning.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Happy Monday everybody.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Incredible interview with Devin Nunes, the Congressman, Head of the House Intelligence Committee. So I can't wait to hear that again this morning.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's just a -- it's extraordinary. We've talked about how the same FBI agents were overseeing an investigation into Trump and an investigation into Hillary Clinton's e-mail usage.

And now we find out that with all of the evidence on the Hillary Clinton side, they didn't have any official intelligence to launch this investigation. It sounds like Dagen it was all about the dossier.

MCDOWELL: All about the dossier. And that it -- again, this is a thread that runs through. The very highest leadership within the FBI and it's incredible that -- I mean, it really is Devin Nunes who's taking this on to uncover why a presidential campaign was being investigated.

BARTIROMO: That's right. And he's getting trashed for it at every level. And yet he's the Chairman of the Intel Committee and has looked at the raw data and has come up with this, that there was no intelligence used. Quite extraordinary, we're going to talk about that this morning and what that means.

Joining the conversation, we've got House Majority Leader, California Congressman Kevin McCarthy in the studio this morning. White House Principal Deputy Press Secretary Raj Shah is here. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano along with former U.S. Attorney and Avenue Strategies Partner, Budd Cummings.

Don't miss a moment of it, we've got a lot on the table this morning to talk about. And, of course, we are also looking at earnings. Investors are weighing for Google's parent company Alphabet to report earnings after the close tonight as the technology giant gears up to report the results and tell us what the last three months look like. Analysts expecting the company to post adjusted earnings of $9.28 a share on revenue of $3.29 billion. Alphabet is kicking off big techs earnings splits on Wall Street this week. We also have Amazon coming out on Thursday. Mike Murphy, your thoughts?

MURPHY: I think when you see a move in big tech like you saw Apple on Friday dropped seven points, I think in this market it's a buying opportunity. So, Google's going to -- Alphabet's going to come out with earnings and say, "We're going to hear from Amazon" all the big tech companies, they're all going to post great numbers.

How the stock reacts, I think the way to play it is if there's a pullback, it's a buying opportunity because we have underlying strength in the market, you have underlying strength in these companies. So any weakness, I'd be a buyer.

BARTIROMO: Maybe but Dan Niles from Alpha One who's really very thoughtful on the tech sector, he was my guest on the Wall Street program this weekend and he said Apple's going to miss and Amazon -- and Google parent, Alphabet is going to miss.

Now, if you had that big sharp decline on Apple on Friday, does the market -- is the market telling you get ready for a miss and all are we going to see an even bigger decline if the company comes out and reports a miss?

MURPHY: You may. But remember, Apple under most recent pull off came all the way down to $151 and right after that, it rallied all the way back up to $170. So here, where it's trading in the mid $160s, it's setting up after Friday's move, it -- I think you're pricing a miss into the stock.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MURPHY: So if there's any more weakness, I'd be a buyer. But if Apple misses by a few millions, iPhone Xs in the market, I think that sets up as a buying opportunity because they have so many other levers that they can pull. I think that people are going to be buying iPhones in the third quarter, in the fourth quarter, so any weakness is a buying.

CARTER: Do you think --

BARTIROMO: You should drop the X. People don't like the X and they've got expectations that it's going to not meet demand numbers.

MCDOWELL: It's a flop. According to some, if you talk to -- I'm not doing channel checks but I go and -- yes, I've talked to a lot of people who work in the data -- the cellphone company in the stores, not for Apple but like -- I won't use the name of the company because I don't want to get the employees in trouble.

BARTIROMO: But they would know.

MCDOWELL: But they tell me if I go in and say, "Do you like the X?" They're like, "No, don't buy it. It really is awful." They were like, "If you tried an Android phone" so that would certainly benefit Google.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, people are unhappy with it. And --

BARTIROMO: I haven't had the easiest, same as mine.

MCDOWELL: It's a $1,000, that's a huge outlay.

BARTIROMO: Yes, expensive.

MCDOWELL: At a time when Americans really are keeping the purse strings pretty tight in terms of their spending.

MURPHY: One thing on that, if you're going to buy an X, it's 24 months and they charge $50.00 a month automatically. So they're giving you an interest for a loan to finance the purchase of the phone. So I think people like that. And I think no matter what, people are going to buy the next Apple phone, so I think that's the --

CARTER: If it was selling off the shelf by itself though they wouldn't have to do that, right?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MURPHY: Well, I think you have to define off the shelf -- well no, I think that's part of their plan. So number one, off the shelves, they may miss numbers at top line expectations but they're still selling a ton of iPhone Xs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what Dan Niles said about this is that they -- he said him and his whole family needed new batteries. And so they went and changed the battery in the phone and it was $29.00 and they were fine.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And he said, "I don't need to buy a new phone," he said. And so I'm looking at my family as a proxy and saying, "Well all we did was buy a $29.00 battery and we were good to go and we didn't need the next phone." So that's what he's worried about, the next phone and, of course, the issues around the X which are real.

CARTER: Yes. I also am curious with regulation if fears are going to play into stock prices after earnings this week because I know so many people are talking about, is tech going to be the next area that's going to be highly regulated like banks were before with all of the data concerns, with everything that's with Facebook.

MCDOWELL: That goes right to what Maria mentioned at the top of the show about the -- this Wall Street Journal story on the amount of information that Google collects on you, (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: And the article is called, "Who has more of your data? Your personal data than Facebook? Try Google." The Journal reporting that Google's android devices allowed the harvesting of data from billions of active users without warning.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The grave site for Barbara Bush will be opening to the public this morning. Cheryl Casone with the details now, Cheryl.

CASONE: Maria, the late first lady was buried over the weekend in a gated plot at the George H.W. Bush presidential library. She is now near the grave of her daughter, Robin, who died from leukemia when she was just three years old. The Bush family, sharing photos from the private ceremony, hundreds of family and friends giving a final farewell. This day brought together for former presidents-- the two President Bushes, as well as Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, the first lady is also there, including Melania Trump. This photo has gone viral, we should say. And in a tribute to his wife's commitment to literacy, former President Bush wore a pair of socks decorated with stacks of colorful books.

Well, celebrity health expert Dr. Oz has captured this video of a burning bus on the New Jersey turnpike with high school students running away. Dr. Oz pulled over to film the chaotic scene and made sure the students got to safety. A staff can be seen carrying luggage, instruments away from that bus. That group was coming back from a musical in New York. Dr. Oz shared the video on his Facebook page, saying he was thankful that everybody got out safely. This is not Dr. Oz's first roadside rescue. He was in an honorary firefighter after helping victims of a crash on the same highway back in 2015.

Well, the China's largest music streaming 10 Cent Music is preparing to go public. They're expected to be one of the biggest technology IPOs ever. This valuation could exceed $25 billion. 10 Cent Music says it has got about 700 million monthly active users. This coming, of course, after Spotify successfully went public on the New York Stock Exchange earlier this month.

And let's stay with music because Rihanna is planning to reduce -- release a line of lingerie. The singer modeling the collection herself. She posts in her underwear on Instagram. Not clear when exactly her new products are actually going to be released. But last year, he successfully launched her own make up line during New York Fashion Week. Another celebrity, Maria, getting on the I'm-going-to-make-and-sell-it-too bandwagon, and she's probably doing pretty well. Her makeup is done very well, we should say.

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes, that's been a real success. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Expanding her empire.

MURPHY: More power to her. I love it. She's got the music, she's got the make-up, she's got lingerie. Awesome! I love to see that.

BARTIROMO: You want to say something?

CARTER: I just want to say how much I love the picture of the Bush family with all of the presidents at the funeral. I love H.W.'s socks.

BARTIROMO: Yes, they're great. Coming up, as companies transform the way we work, live, and play, the way the start-ups look for office face to stuck in that time work. That's where Squarefoot comes in. The details on the real estate disruptor right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Ahead winds for growing business is finding office space. The one company, Squarefoot, is trying to make the process a lot easier and more transparent now. The company recently announced it has raised $7 million in a series eight round financing that led by Mike Murphy and his firm Rosecliffe with us this morning. Mike is now joining Squarefoot's board of directors and joining us right now to talk more about it is the CEO and co-Founder of Squarefoot, Jonathan Wasserstrum. Good to see you, Jonathan. Thanks for joining us.

JONATHAN WASSERSTRUM, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, SQUAREFOOT: Thanks for having me guys.

BARTIROMO: So, we know about the retail market and things like truly in the market. Tell us how your firm differs from the competition and how you try to provide transparency in real estate.

WASSERSTRUM: Yes, groups like (INAUDIBLE) have done a great job on their essential side pushing forward that transparency. When we start the business several years ago, we thought it was stupid that you couldn't go online and do the same thing for office space -- that's what we set out to do.

BARTIROMO: How do you do it?

WASSERSTRUM: Well, we do a couple of things: we bring transparency to that market that traditionally had none by allowing prospective tenants to go online and look at space. And we also have technology that we have built for in-house transactions team and for the clients who we work with to guide them to that process to make it a whole bunch more easy.

MURPHY: So, we were first introduced to Jonathan when we are moving our offices from midtown down to the flat iron district. And just going online and searching for space, we saw the Squarefoot -- that's how we originally met them. And we see an opportunity for them to bring to the commercial market what companies like Compass and Red Thin have done for their residential market. So, now, if you want to find an office, office space, you go right on their site, to Squarefoot.com, you look at what you want: how many feet, how many employees, what you want to spend, and they'll pull it up for you right on your smartphones. So, we think this is how people will get office space in the future.

CARTER: it's pretty extraordinary. We're talking about one of the things. I was wondering what happens to commercial real estate with trends both in and how people were working, and also, we're talking a little bit about what that means of retail space right now in so many empty store fronts. Can you tell me a little bit about that?

WASSERSTRUM: Yes. It's a way that people are working. There's been a proliferation with groups like we work and all the flexible space writers. We think it's great for the industry. It brings a whole much more flexibility to the market. It means transactions can happen a lot quicker. The traditional leases of three to five years or maybe a thin of the past? I don't think I'd go that far. I think it depends on the right solution for the right company at the right time. Retail has been a really interesting thing, and everybody has been reading and talking about the death of retail for a while. It's probably a little bit overblown in my opinion. I think that it just takes a little bit to reset pricing expectations now from historically where companies can make a whole bunch of money with retail outlets, but a lot of that is moving online. So, we're just going to have to start adjusting sale price and expectations.

MCDOWELL: What about the pushback from traditional commercial real estate brokers and how they might be retaliating against you? Because they're not going to standby and just take it.

WASSERSTRUM: Hopefully, they won't be marching the streets too soon. So, we are brokers ourselves, so we work within the confines of the traditional industry. There's really two groups from the brokers' perspective: there's the groups that represent landlords, and there's the groups that represent tenants. To those who represent the landlords, we're their bestfriend, where a whole new conduit that they've never had for them to access people actually looking for the space in the market. And for the groups that represent the tenants -- you know, the groups like I used to work at a guy who runs real estate for us now. I used to work at (INAUDIBLE) -- they focus more on the big guys, right? So, Fox needs office space, or the average 500,000 Squarefoot user needs office space, you should work with JLL. Great! I'm (INAUDIBLE). I work with them. But for the average five, 10, 50, even 200 person company, you should be online looking with us, and helping us, and allowing us to help you with your transactions.

BARTIROMO: Real quick, how is the market right? A lot movement or no?

WASSERSTRUM: A lot of movement, yes. Softening a little bit at the top, but there's always going to be people who needs space.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan, great to see you.

WASSERSTRUM: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching. Good luck. Jonathan Wasserstrum there. Still ahead, Iran, Syria trade, all pressing issues on the agenda as President Trump welcomes the French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House for a three-day visit in Washington. We are taking your live to the White House with a preview, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Monday to you! It is Monday, April 23rd.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S5X-J7H1-JBHT-D44C-00000-00WSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office Space2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:48:08ZLexisNexisWSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office SpaceLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there ladies, thank you so much. Happy Monday to you and good morning everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, thanks for joining us. It is Monday, April 23rd. Your top stories right now 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings on the driver seat on Wall Street this morning, Futures showing a decline at the start of trading today, down about 40 points on the Dow, down a fraction on the S&P, and down eight points on the NASDAQ. More than a third of the Dow and the S&P500 set to report their first quarter earnings this week. It is going to be a monster week for earnings.

Alphabet, the name to watch after the close tonight, it comes amid new concerns surrounding Google's data collection. Dan Niles Money Manager on Wall Street this weekend says he thinks Google will miss earnings estimates.

Markets tumbling on Friday, Apple dragged the Dow lower after analysts' reports suggested that smartphone sales could slow in the coming months. Also, Niles said Apple will miss. We are watching the fine market this morning, the 10-year yield creeping closer to three percent, take a look, up two basis points right now at 2.99 percent on the 10-year.

In Europe this morning, stocks looking like this, now we do have a lower opening there as well and lower trading this morning. CAC Quarante is down a fraction, CAC Quarante in Paris down a fraction as is the DAX Index in Germany, down a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight right across the board, the Hang Seng the biggest loser, down better than one-half of one percent in Hong Kong.

And a pair of former political outsiders inside the Oval Office, President Trump welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House today from trade to national security. We're taking a look at what's on the agenda for the two world leaders ahead of the state dinner tomorrow night.

Investigating the investigation, shocking new revelations on the start of the FBI probe into the Trump campaign. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes telling me yesterday about his findings, he explained on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE CHAIRMAN: We've long wanted to know what intelligence did you have that actually led to this investigation. So what we found now after the investigators have reviewed it is that in fact there was no intelligence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: No intelligence to launch that investigation. The very latest on the investigation coming up. Plus, another high note for the music industry, Chinese streaming giant Tencent reportedly planning to go public where the company is expected to list and that mammoth evaluation.

Plus, revving up their resume, Harley-Davidson offering an internship of a lifetime, how college students can get paid to ride coming up.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to talk about it, FOX BUsines Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO, Managing Partner, Mike Murphy along with Pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter. Good morning.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Happy Monday everybody.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Incredible interview with Devin Nunes, the Congressman, Head of the House Intelligence Committee. So I can't wait to hear that again this morning.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's just a -- it's extraordinary. We've talked about how the same FBI agents were overseeing an investigation into Trump and an investigation into Hillary Clinton's e-mail usage.

And now we find out that with all of the evidence on the Hillary Clinton side, they didn't have any official intelligence to launch this investigation. It sounds like Dagen it was all about the dossier.

MCDOWELL: All about the dossier. And that it -- again, this is a thread that runs through. The very highest leadership within the FBI and it's incredible that -- I mean, it really is Devin Nunes who's taking this on to uncover why a presidential campaign was being investigated.

BARTIROMO: That's right. And he's getting trashed for it at every level. And yet he's the Chairman of the Intel Committee and has looked at the raw data and has come up with this, that there was no intelligence used. Quite extraordinary, we're going to talk about that this morning and what that means.

Joining the conversation, we've got House Majority Leader, California Congressman Kevin McCarthy in the studio this morning. White House Principal Deputy Press Secretary Raj Shah is here. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano along with former U.S. Attorney and Avenue Strategies Partner, Budd Cummings.

Don't miss a moment of it, we've got a lot on the table this morning to talk about. And, of course, we are also looking at earnings. Investors are weighing for Google's parent company Alphabet to report earnings after the close tonight as the technology giant gears up to report the results and tell us what the last three months look like. Analysts expecting the company to post adjusted earnings of $9.28 a share on revenue of $3.29 billion. Alphabet is kicking off big techs earnings splits on Wall Street this week. We also have Amazon coming out on Thursday. Mike Murphy, your thoughts?

MURPHY: I think when you see a move in big tech like you saw Apple on Friday dropped seven points, I think in this market it's a buying opportunity. So, Google's going to -- Alphabet's going to come out with earnings and say, "We're going to hear from Amazon" all the big tech companies, they're all going to post great numbers.

How the stock reacts, I think the way to play it is if there's a pullback, it's a buying opportunity because we have underlying strength in the market, you have underlying strength in these companies. So any weakness, I'd be a buyer.

BARTIROMO: Maybe but Dan Niles from Alpha One who's really very thoughtful on the tech sector, he was my guest on the Wall Street program this weekend and he said Apple's going to miss and Amazon -- and Google parent, Alphabet is going to miss.

Now, if you had that big sharp decline on Apple on Friday, does the market -- is the market telling you get ready for a miss and all are we going to see an even bigger decline if the company comes out and reports a miss?

MURPHY: You may. But remember, Apple under most recent pull off came all the way down to $151 and right after that, it rallied all the way back up to $170. So here, where it's trading in the mid $160s, it's setting up after Friday's move, it -- I think you're pricing a miss into the stock.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MURPHY: So if there's any more weakness, I'd be a buyer. But if Apple misses by a few millions, iPhone Xs in the market, I think that sets up as a buying opportunity because they have so many other levers that they can pull. I think that people are going to be buying iPhones in the third quarter, in the fourth quarter, so any weakness is a buying.

CARTER: Do you think --

BARTIROMO: You should drop the X. People don't like the X and they've got expectations that it's going to not meet demand numbers.

MCDOWELL: It's a flop. According to some, if you talk to -- I'm not doing channel checks but I go and -- yes, I've talked to a lot of people who work in the data -- the cellphone company in the stores, not for Apple but like -- I won't use the name of the company because I don't want to get the employees in trouble.

BARTIROMO: But they would know.

MCDOWELL: But they tell me if I go in and say, "Do you like the X?" They're like, "No, don't buy it. It really is awful." They were like, "If you tried an Android phone" so that would certainly benefit Google.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, people are unhappy with it. And --

BARTIROMO: I haven't had the easiest, same as mine.

MCDOWELL: It's a $1,000, that's a huge outlay.

BARTIROMO: Yes, expensive.

MCDOWELL: At a time when Americans really are keeping the purse strings pretty tight in terms of their spending.

MURPHY: One thing on that, if you're going to buy an X, it's 24 months and they charge $50.00 a month automatically. So they're giving you an interest for a loan to finance the purchase of the phone. So I think people like that. And I think no matter what, people are going to buy the next Apple phone, so I think that's the --

CARTER: If it was selling off the shelf by itself though they wouldn't have to do that, right?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MURPHY: Well, I think you have to define off the shelf -- well no, I think that's part of their plan. So number one, off the shelves, they may miss numbers at top line expectations but they're still selling a ton of iPhone Xs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what Dan Niles said about this is that they -- he said him and his whole family needed new batteries. And so they went and changed the battery in the phone and it was $29.00 and they were fine.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And he said, "I don't need to buy a new phone," he said. And so I'm looking at my family as a proxy and saying, "Well all we did was buy a $29.00 battery and we were good to go and we didn't need the next phone." So that's what he's worried about, the next phone and, of course, the issues around the X which are real.

CARTER: Yes. I also am curious with regulation if fears are going to play into stock prices after earnings this week because I know so many people are talking about, is tech going to be the next area that's going to be highly regulated like banks were before with all of the data concerns, with everything that's with Facebook.

MCDOWELL: That goes right to what Maria mentioned at the top of the show about the -- this Wall Street Journal story on the amount of information that Google collects on you, (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: And the article is called, "Who has more of your data? Your personal data than Facebook? Try Google." The Journal reporting that Google's android devices allowed the harvesting of data from billions of active users without warning.

What about that? I mean, I'm talking eight years ago I did a documentary on Google and that was about the fact that they save all your searches for two years and then they anonymize the math to two years but why do they say for the two years anyway?

MURPHY: I guess to monetize them, they want to figure out how they can --

BARTIROMO: There you go.

MURPHY: -- get advertising dollars in by using a data. But I think where we are today in 2018, if you're on the internet, if you're on your smart phone, if you're searching on a computer, if you're searching anywhere, there are ways for whether it's Google or Apple or Facebook, somebody can track what you're doing.

Now, if you don't like that, I guess there are certain ways to try to backdoor it or opt out of certain things. But, I think that's just a fact of life, people are going to know what was --

BARTIROMO: Yes. But what did Sheryl Sandberg say, Dagen? She said, "Oh, we don't have a product to opt out at the high levels, that's a paid product." In other words, I have to pay them just to secure my data that is not shared.

MCDOWELL: That's an idea that should -- that actually Walt Mossberg came up with. Like, he suggested that Facebook offer a paid service and -- so they wouldn't share of your data.

But this Wall Street Journal article goes into the fact that Google, if you're logged into Google, you can opt out of how they use your private information. But it goes well beyond that because Google Analytics is used on about 50 million sites and Google Analytics tracks you whether you're logged in or not, so that's number one. But Google uses among other things, you're browsing in search history apps, you've installed demographics like age and gender from its own analytics and other sources where -- and other sources like where we've shopped in the real world.

It's incredible Google's reach and I think that the point of this article in the Wall Street Journal is Mark Zuckerberg gets called in front of Congress, he -- and gets grilled about regulation, same thing's going to happen to Alphabet and Google and Google out to be a little bit more worried than even Facebook --

BARTIROMO: So what does that mean?

MCDOWELL: -- about regulation, what are they going to do? Are -- is there going to be a broad way you can prevent Google from collecting your information whether you're -- even if you aren't logged into the Google service.

BARTIROMO: And with new rules, how much does that impact the earnings and does that change the (INAUDIBLE) on the stock?

MURPHY: Right. Well that's why these companies have been so profitable is that they can sell your data to advertisers and advertisers know exactly who you are --

BARTIROMO: And we didn't realize how much they were selling.

MURPHY: I guess maybe people didn't know exactly how much they were selling but I think when you went on to the site, I think you knew. When you logged in to your computer and looked Mexican vacations, the next time you log in, there are six sites popping up that are focused on Mexican resorts or Mexican vacations. I mean, that's been going on for years from these companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: But I think that people knew that sort of thing but I don't think they understood how that translated to so many other -- other things. And that the data might used not for what they want it to be used for.

So if you Google Mexican vacations or getting Mexican vacations, that makes sense to people. But when they have -- you have a whole profile online that says this is who they think you are, your age and that the kinds of ads are going to serve up based on that, I think a lot Americans are confused by that and quite frankly are angry that that's happened because they don't feel it's been transparent to them at all.

BARTIROMO: And by the way, when you're in a certain place in the world and all of a sudden you get an ad for that local store that's on the block that you were in, that's a little spooky --

CARTER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- I'm sorry. I'm going to switch gears to the White House, President Trump welcoming French Leader Emmanuel Macron today to Washington for a three-day visit. The two are expected to talk about trade ahead of his trip. The French president issued a warning to the United States, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE: You cannot make war with your ally. It's too complicated. If you make war against everybody, you'll make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war (INAUDIBLE) come on, it's not -- it doesn't work. You need ally, we are the ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And yet he still agrees with many of President Trump's policies, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: This goes back to something I've talked about repeatedly is that our allies in terms of trade and on the world stage, we're kind of blindsided by the steel and aluminum tariffs.

If you want -- if you really want to take on China, if China is your biggest problem globally in terms of unfair trade practices, then you lock arms with Europe, with Japan and you present a united front. When you kind of throw a steel and aluminum tariff in the face of your allies and say, "Maybe we'll exempt you, maybe we won't." And there have been many exemptions it turned out.

But, again, it was handled so haphazardly and so ham-handedly right out of the gate with the holding up the -- you got the Commerce Secretary holding up cans of soup and lecturing the American people about your -- the cost of this can of soup isn't going on. It shows the fundamental misunderstanding of how people will react to inflation and, again, inflation by fiat out of the White House but also it was a slap on the face to our allies if they weren't consulted about it in the first place. WASSERSTRUM: Yes. It's a way that people are working. There's been a proliferation with groups like we work and all the flexible space writers. We think it's great for the industry. It brings a whole much more flexibility to the market. It means transactions can happen a lot quicker. The traditional leases of three to five years or maybe a thin of the past? I don't think I'd go that far. I think it depends on the right solution for the right company at the right time. Retail has been a really interesting thing, and everybody has been reading and talking about the death of retail for a while. It's probably a little bit overblown in my opinion. I think that it just takes a little bit to reset pricing expectations now from historically where companies can make a whole bunch of money with retail outlets, but a lot of that is moving online. So, we're just going to have to start adjusting sale price and expectations.

MCDOWELL: What about the pushback from traditional commercial real estate brokers and how they might be retaliating against you? Because they're not going to standby and just take it.

WASSERSTRUM: Hopefully, they won't be marching the streets too soon. So, we are brokers ourselves, so we work within the confines of the traditional industry. There's really two groups from the brokers' perspective: there's the groups that represent landlords, and there's the groups that represent tenants. To those who represent the landlords, we're their bestfriend, where a whole new conduit that they've never had for them to access people actually looking for the space in the market. And for the groups that represent the tenants -- you know, the groups like I used to work at a guy who runs real estate for us now. I used to work at (INAUDIBLE) -- they focus more on the big guys, right? So, Fox needs office space, or the average 500,000 Squarefoot user needs office space, you should work with JLL. Great! I'm (INAUDIBLE). I work with them. But for the average five, 10, 50, even 200 person company, you should be online looking with us, and helping us, and allowing us to help you with your transactions.

BARTIROMO: Real quick, how is the market right? A lot movement or no?

WASSERSTRUM: A lot of movement, yes. Softening a little bit at the top, but there's always going to be people who needs space.

BARTIROMO: Jonathan, great to see you.

WASSERSTRUM: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching. Good luck. Jonathan Wasserstrum there. Still ahead, Iran, Syria trade, all pressing issues on the agenda as President Trump welcomes the French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House for a three-day visit in Washington. We are taking your live to the White House with a preview, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. Happy Monday to you! It is Monday, April 23rd.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WCJ-3S61-JBHT-D4FB-00000-00WSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office Space2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:48:08ZLexisNexisWSJ: Google Has More of Your Personal Data than Facebook; Trump- Macron Meeting; Rising Rates Weigh on Market; Nunes Collusion with Russia?; 'No Intelligence' to Justify a Trump Campaign Collusion Probe; Awan Family Data Breach; Barbara Bush Honored; Squarefoot Digital Real Estate Brokerage Focused On Office SpaceLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Hey there ladies, thank you so much. Happy Monday to you and good morning everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, thanks for joining us. It is Monday, April 23rd. Your top stories right now 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings on the driver seat on Wall Street this morning, Futures showing a decline at the start of trading today, down about 40 points on the Dow, down a fraction on the S&P, and down eight points on the NASDAQ. More than a third of the Dow and the S&P500 set to report their first quarter earnings this week. It is going to be a monster week for earnings.

Alphabet, the name to watch after the close tonight, it comes amid new concerns surrounding Google's data collection. Dan Niles Money Manager on Wall Street this weekend says he thinks Google will miss earnings estimates.

Markets tumbling on Friday, Apple dragged the Dow lower after analysts' reports suggested that smartphone sales could slow in the coming months. Also, Niles said Apple will miss. We are watching the fine market this morning, the 10-year yield creeping closer to three percent, take a look, up two basis points right now at 2.99 percent on the 10-year.

In Europe this morning, stocks looking like this, now we do have a lower opening there as well and lower trading this morning. CAC Quarante is down a fraction, CAC Quarante in Paris down a fraction as is the DAX Index in Germany, down a quarter of a percent.

In Asia overnight right across the board, the Hang Seng the biggest loser, down better than one-half of one percent in Hong Kong.

And a pair of former political outsiders inside the Oval Office, President Trump welcoming French President Emmanuel Macron to the White House today from trade to national security. We're taking a look at what's on the agenda for the two world leaders ahead of the state dinner tomorrow night.

Investigating the investigation, shocking new revelations on the start of the FBI probe into the Trump campaign. House Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes telling me yesterday about his findings, he explained on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. DEVIN NUNES (R-CA), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE CHAIRMAN: We've long wanted to know what intelligence did you have that actually led to this investigation. So what we found now after the investigators have reviewed it is that in fact there was no intelligence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: No intelligence to launch that investigation. The very latest on the investigation coming up. Plus, another high note for the music industry, Chinese streaming giant Tencent reportedly planning to go public where the company is expected to list and that mammoth evaluation.

Plus, revving up their resume, Harley-Davidson offering an internship of a lifetime, how college students can get paid to ride coming up.

All those stories coming up this Monday morning and joining me to talk about it, FOX BUsines Network's Dagen McDowell. Rosecliff CEO, Managing Partner, Mike Murphy along with Pollster and the President of Maslansky and Partners, Lee Carter. Good morning.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Good morning. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Happy Monday everybody.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: Good morning Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: Incredible interview with Devin Nunes, the Congressman, Head of the House Intelligence Committee. So I can't wait to hear that again this morning.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's just a -- it's extraordinary. We've talked about how the same FBI agents were overseeing an investigation into Trump and an investigation into Hillary Clinton's e-mail usage.

And now we find out that with all of the evidence on the Hillary Clinton side, they didn't have any official intelligence to launch this investigation. It sounds like Dagen it was all about the dossier.

MCDOWELL: All about the dossier. And that it -- again, this is a thread that runs through. The very highest leadership within the FBI and it's incredible that -- I mean, it really is Devin Nunes who's taking this on to uncover why a presidential campaign was being investigated.

BARTIROMO: That's right. And he's getting trashed for it at every level. And yet he's the Chairman of the Intel Committee and has looked at the raw data and has come up with this, that there was no intelligence used. Quite extraordinary, we're going to talk about that this morning and what that means.

Joining the conversation, we've got House Majority Leader, California Congressman Kevin McCarthy in the studio this morning. White House Principal Deputy Press Secretary Raj Shah is here. FOX News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano along with former U.S. Attorney and Avenue Strategies Partner, Budd Cummings.

Don't miss a moment of it, we've got a lot on the table this morning to talk about. And, of course, we are also looking at earnings. Investors are weighing for Google's parent company Alphabet to report earnings after the close tonight as the technology giant gears up to report the results and tell us what the last three months look like. Analysts expecting the company to post adjusted earnings of $9.28 a share on revenue of $3.29 billion. Alphabet is kicking off big techs earnings splits on Wall Street this week. We also have Amazon coming out on Thursday. Mike Murphy, your thoughts?

MURPHY: I think when you see a move in big tech like you saw Apple on Friday dropped seven points, I think in this market it's a buying opportunity. So, Google's going to -- Alphabet's going to come out with earnings and say, "We're going to hear from Amazon" all the big tech companies, they're all going to post great numbers.

How the stock reacts, I think the way to play it is if there's a pullback, it's a buying opportunity because we have underlying strength in the market, you have underlying strength in these companies. So any weakness, I'd be a buyer.

BARTIROMO: Maybe but Dan Niles from Alpha One who's really very thoughtful on the tech sector, he was my guest on the Wall Street program this weekend and he said Apple's going to miss and Amazon -- and Google parent, Alphabet is going to miss.

Now, if you had that big sharp decline on Apple on Friday, does the market -- is the market telling you get ready for a miss and all are we going to see an even bigger decline if the company comes out and reports a miss?

MURPHY: You may. But remember, Apple under most recent pull off came all the way down to $151 and right after that, it rallied all the way back up to $170. So here, where it's trading in the mid $160s, it's setting up after Friday's move, it -- I think you're pricing a miss into the stock.

BARTIROMO: OK.

MURPHY: So if there's any more weakness, I'd be a buyer. But if Apple misses by a few millions, iPhone Xs in the market, I think that sets up as a buying opportunity because they have so many other levers that they can pull. I think that people are going to be buying iPhones in the third quarter, in the fourth quarter, so any weakness is a buying.

CARTER: Do you think --

BARTIROMO: You should drop the X. People don't like the X and they've got expectations that it's going to not meet demand numbers.

MCDOWELL: It's a flop. According to some, if you talk to -- I'm not doing channel checks but I go and -- yes, I've talked to a lot of people who work in the data -- the cellphone company in the stores, not for Apple but like -- I won't use the name of the company because I don't want to get the employees in trouble.

BARTIROMO: But they would know.

MCDOWELL: But they tell me if I go in and say, "Do you like the X?" They're like, "No, don't buy it. It really is awful." They were like, "If you tried an Android phone" so that would certainly benefit Google.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But, again, people are unhappy with it. And --

BARTIROMO: I haven't had the easiest, same as mine.

MCDOWELL: It's a $1,000, that's a huge outlay.

BARTIROMO: Yes, expensive.

MCDOWELL: At a time when Americans really are keeping the purse strings pretty tight in terms of their spending.

MURPHY: One thing on that, if you're going to buy an X, it's 24 months and they charge $50.00 a month automatically. So they're giving you an interest for a loan to finance the purchase of the phone. So I think people like that. And I think no matter what, people are going to buy the next Apple phone, so I think that's the --

CARTER: If it was selling off the shelf by itself though they wouldn't have to do that, right?

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MURPHY: Well, I think you have to define off the shelf -- well no, I think that's part of their plan. So number one, off the shelves, they may miss numbers at top line expectations but they're still selling a ton of iPhone Xs.

BARTIROMO: Yes. You know what Dan Niles said about this is that they -- he said him and his whole family needed new batteries. And so they went and changed the battery in the phone and it was $29.00 and they were fine.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: And he said, "I don't need to buy a new phone," he said. And so I'm looking at my family as a proxy and saying, "Well all we did was buy a $29.00 battery and we were good to go and we didn't need the next phone." So that's what he's worried about, the next phone and, of course, the issues around the X which are real.

CARTER: Yes. I also am curious with regulation if fears are going to play into stock prices after earnings this week because I know so many people are talking about, is tech going to be the next area that's going to be highly regulated like banks were before with all of the data concerns, with everything that's with Facebook.

MCDOWELL: That goes right to what Maria mentioned at the top of the show about the -- this Wall Street Journal story on the amount of information that Google collects on you, (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: And the article is called, "Who has more of your data? Your personal data than Facebook? Try Google." The Journal reporting that Google's android devices allowed the harvesting of data from billions of active users without warning.

What about that? I mean, I'm talking eight years ago I did a documentary on Google and that was about the fact that they save all your searches for two years and then they anonymize the math to two years but why do they say for the two years anyway?

MURPHY: I guess to monetize them, they want to figure out how they can --

BARTIROMO: There you go.

MURPHY: -- get advertising dollars in by using a data. But I think where we are today in 2018, if you're on the internet, if you're on your smart phone, if you're searching on a computer, if you're searching anywhere, there are ways for whether it's Google or Apple or Facebook, somebody can track what you're doing.

Now, if you don't like that, I guess there are certain ways to try to backdoor it or opt out of certain things. But, I think that's just a fact of life, people are going to know what was --

BARTIROMO: Yes. But what did Sheryl Sandberg say, Dagen? She said, "Oh, we don't have a product to opt out at the high levels, that's a paid product." In other words, I have to pay them just to secure my data that is not shared.

MCDOWELL: That's an idea that should -- that actually Walt Mossberg came up with. Like, he suggested that Facebook offer a paid service and -- so they wouldn't share of your data.

But this Wall Street Journal article goes into the fact that Google, if you're logged into Google, you can opt out of how they use your private information. But it goes well beyond that because Google Analytics is used on about 50 million sites and Google Analytics tracks you whether you're logged in or not, so that's number one. But Google uses among other things, you're browsing in search history apps, you've installed demographics like age and gender from its own analytics and other sources where -- and other sources like where we've shopped in the real world.

It's incredible Google's reach and I think that the point of this article in the Wall Street Journal is Mark Zuckerberg gets called in front of Congress, he -- and gets grilled about regulation, same thing's going to happen to Alphabet and Google and Google out to be a little bit more worried than even Facebook --

BARTIROMO: So what does that mean?

MCDOWELL: -- about regulation, what are they going to do? Are -- is there going to be a broad way you can prevent Google from collecting your information whether you're -- even if you aren't logged into the Google service.

BARTIROMO: And with new rules, how much does that impact the earnings and does that change the (INAUDIBLE) on the stock?

MURPHY: Right. Well that's why these companies have been so profitable is that they can sell your data to advertisers and advertisers know exactly who you are --

BARTIROMO: And we didn't realize how much they were selling.

MURPHY: I guess maybe people didn't know exactly how much they were selling but I think when you went on to the site, I think you knew. When you logged in to your computer and looked Mexican vacations, the next time you log in, there are six sites popping up that are focused on Mexican resorts or Mexican vacations. I mean, that's been going on for years from these companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CARTER: But I think that people knew that sort of thing but I don't think they understood how that translated to so many other -- other things. And that the data might used not for what they want it to be used for.

So if you Google Mexican vacations or getting Mexican vacations, that makes sense to people. But when they have -- you have a whole profile online that says this is who they think you are, your age and that the kinds of ads are going to serve up based on that, I think a lot Americans are confused by that and quite frankly are angry that that's happened because they don't feel it's been transparent to them at all.

BARTIROMO: And by the way, when you're in a certain place in the world and all of a sudden you get an ad for that local store that's on the block that you were in, that's a little spooky --

CARTER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- I'm sorry. I'm going to switch gears to the White House, President Trump welcoming French Leader Emmanuel Macron today to Washington for a three-day visit. The two are expected to talk about trade ahead of his trip. The French president issued a warning to the United States, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EMMANUEL MACRON, PRESIDENT OF FRANCE: You cannot make war with your ally. It's too complicated. If you make war against everybody, you'll make trade war against China, trade war against Europe, war in Syria, war (INAUDIBLE) come on, it's not -- it doesn't work. You need ally, we are the ally.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And yet he still agrees with many of President Trump's policies, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: This goes back to something I've talked about repeatedly is that our allies in terms of trade and on the world stage, we're kind of blindsided by the steel and aluminum tariffs.

If you want -- if you really want to take on China, if China is your biggest problem globally in terms of unfair trade practices, then you lock arms with Europe, with Japan and you present a united front. When you kind of throw a steel and aluminum tariff in the face of your allies and say, "Maybe we'll exempt you, maybe we won't." And there have been many exemptions it turned out.

But, again, it was handled so haphazardly and so ham-handedly right out of the gate with the holding up the -- you got the Commerce Secretary holding up cans of soup and lecturing the American people about your -- the cost of this can of soup isn't going on. It shows the fundamental misunderstanding of how people will react to inflation and, again, inflation by fiat out of the White House but also it was a slap on the face to our allies if they weren't consulted about it in the first place. They're trying to manage it now but, again, they're still -- he still got his hair up so to speak.

BARTIROMO: Messaging issues I guess.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll take a break. When we come back, no official intelligence was used to start the Russia investigation, the so-called collusion. The jaw-dropping revelation from House Intel Committee Chairman Devin Nunes after digging deeper into FBI and DOJ documents, the new questions in the case, that's right after this break.

And then Tencent, China's largest music streaming company could launch one of the biggest technology IPOs ever with a monster valuation. The staggering number right ahead, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well a massive manhunt is underway this morning for the man suspected of killing four people at a Waffle House outside of Nashville. Cheryl Caosne on headlines on that now, over to you Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes Maria, good morning to you. Police say that 29-year-old Travis Reinking is armed and dangerous. National public schools are now in lockdown mode. We learned yesterday that he was arrested in July of 2017 for being in a restricted area near the White House.

More than a year before that, Reinking claimed singer Taylor Swift was stalking him. Customer James Shaw fearing for his life, took a dangerous chance to pounce on the shooter to wrestle at least the gun away.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES SHAW, JR., WAFFLE HOUSE HERO: At the time that he was either reloading or the gun jammed, or whatever happened, is when I ran through the swivel door, I hit him with the swivel door. I managed to get him with one hand on the gun and then I grabbed it from him and I threw it over the countertop.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well the four people who were killed have been identified. Authority say they are Taurean Sanderlin, Joe Perez, Akilah Dasilva, and DeEbony Groves. Sanderlin was an employee at that Waffle House.

Well, more cancellations today for Southwest Airlines, Southwest has cancelled at least 100 scheduled flights today and yesterday they cancelled about 40 to inspect the planes' engines. This comes after last week's accident in Pennsylvania that killed one woman on board. A fan blade broke off ripping a hole to the plane's wing and then it went into the window on Friday. Regulators have ordered emergency inspections on 700 of the same type of engine that was involved in that accident. Shares of Southwest Airlines were down about 17 percent so far this year.

Well, it could be the summer of the hog for some college students. Harley- Davidson planning to pick eight lucky summer interns and teach them how to ride bikes. Then they're going to attend a motorcycle event across the country, document it all for social media. It's a 12-week paid internship open to juniors and seniors who are interested (INAUDIBLE) in social media, communications, public relations, or marketing. Taking a look at shares of Harley-Davidson down about 20 percent so far this year. I got a kick out of the story Maria because my neighbor who's 66 yesterday said to me, "I want a new Harley" and I thought, "Exactly. And you're 66-years-old."

BARTIROMO: Great. What a gig.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Pretty cool. Get the interns to drive them, ride the bike.

MCDOWELL: A well -- this is a well-known problem that Harley-Davidson's been having. What Cheryl mentioned as -- that young people are not buying motorcycles and not riding motorcycles in this country.

MURPHY: They want to get the young people on the motorcycle so they can collect data. See if the big -- it's a theme that they want the data on --

CARTER: It's a big conspiracy.

MURPHY: That they need data.

BARTIROMO: Oh God.

CARTER: (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: We get an enormous shout out to James Shaw, wow, what a hero. Actually in the Waffle House, sees the gunman come in, just moved and acts. Jumps -- pushes the door into him, jumps on him, and removes the guy's gun. There he is, James Shaw just a patron at the Waffle House becomes the hero of the day.

When they found all those magazines and the other bullets in the shooter's jacket, you know that he was there for some serious killing and James Shaw stopped it.

MURPHY: It's great to see a young man being celebrated, to see the FBI around him, clapping for him. I mean, we - like you said a true hero and we should talk about it even more.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. I think he's just terrific.

MCDOWELL: We should keep talking about him.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Every week, let's just talk about him.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) it out, you are such hero.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And to have that kind of courage, wrestle the gun out of his hands. All right, we'll take a break. When we come back, Hillary Clinton is now blaming charlatans and the media for her 2016 election loss. Now it's the media's fault. Her stunning new comments coming up.

And then we are watching global currency this morning as the 10-year Treasury hits a high of -- a four-year high right under three percent. How this may impact this week's European Central Bank meeting as well. Back in a moment right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Futures edging lower this morning, investors are waiting on more earnings. We are expecting a lower opening for the Dow down 28, NASDAQ and S&P down just a fraction. We're also watching the bond market, the yields on the 10-year hitting 2.99 percent, that is the highest level since January 2014.

Joining us right now is Belpointe Chief Strategist, David Nelson. David, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

DAVID NELSON, CHIEF STRATEGIST, BELPOINTE: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: What worries you more, the move towards three percent or the earnings story?

NELSON: The earning story only in the sense that the expectations were just so high coming into this. Just before this earning started, J.P. Morgan was one of the first to report.

I looked at an estimate chart and they had literally gone parabolic going into the earnings. So expectations are high and so far what I've seen, the earnings have been fine. The bigger problem in earning season this time around is technology. And I saw your interview with Dan Niles and hit on a couple of important points.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let's do that right now. Let's see what Dan Niles said about technology. He had a real problem with Apple and Google parent Alphabet. Here's Dan Niles this weekend.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You also think Apple is going to have a miss when it reports.

DAN NILES, FOUNDING PARTNER, ALPHA ONE CAPITAL PARTNERS: Yes, I do.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDJ-H8K1-JDG9-Y41D-00000-00WSJ: House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy Wants a Data-Privacy Law2019-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:48:08ZLexisNexisWSJ: House GOP Leader Kevin McCarthy Wants a Data-Privacy Law

Washington: Office of the House Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy has issued the following news release:

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy backed the idea of national legislation to safeguard consumers’ data privacy, adding a prominent GOP voice to the bipartisan support in Congress for tackling how technology companies amass and use their information.

Lawmakers from both parties in the House and Senate have been working on bills aimed at strengthening individuals’ ability to control their data collected by the biggest technology companies, including Alphabet Inc.’s Google, Facebook Inc. and Apple Inc.

It isn’t yet clear which, if any, legislation could secure enough support to become law. But the comments from Mr. McCarthy and others indicated that there was significant bipartisan support for establishing stronger privacy guidelines.

“There needs to be a national-level regulation, not state-by-state on what we’re going to do about privacy,” Mr. McCarthy, a California Republican, said in an interview Thursday with The Wall Street Journal. “We should know what data you keep on us. We should be able to take our data and be able to delete our data.”

Mr. McCarthy said he plans to introduce legislation that would ensure that people know what data companies are tracking and allow them to transfer or delete that data.

A data-privacy law passed last year in California helped spur action from both Mr. McCarthy and a bipartisan group of lawmakers working on privacy legislation in the Senate. Many view the law, set to take effect in January 2020, as the strictest consumer-privacy law in the U.S

The California law broadens the definition of what constitutes personal information and gives the state’s consumers the right to prohibit the sale of personal data to third parties and opt out of sharing it altogether.

“If California goes into effect and then every other state’s doing one, we’re going to disrupt whatever growth we can have within technology and innovation,” Mr. McCarthy said.

The California law is somewhat similar to Europe’s General Data Protection Regulation, which took effect last year. One difference is that the California measure includes more provisions allowing consumers to opt out of data sharing as opposed to forcing them to opt in before continuing to use online sites.

Passage of the California law helped spur the formation in the U.S Senate of a working group last year that is drafting what its members hope will be landmark data-privacy legislation.

Composed of members of the Commerce Committee, the group includes the panel’s chairman, Roger Wicker (R., Miss.) Sens. Jerry Moran (R., Kan.), Richard Blumenthal (D., Conn.) and Brian Schatz (D., Hawaii). The group this year added two more high-profile lawmakers: Sen. John Thune of South Dakota, now the GOP whip, and Sen. Maria Cantwell of Washington, the committee’s top Democrat.

“My goal is a strong law that’s stronger than California, that’s more workable to innovation than Europe,” Mr. Wicker said Thursday. “And that it’s so acceptable to all parties that we can avoid a patchwork of state-by-state.”

Staff members from the working group are expected to meet Friday to discuss the draft legislation. Mr. Wicker hopes to introduce a bill before the Senate’s August recess, a goal primarily driven by a desire to get the bill passed before the California law takes effect in January, according to a GOP aide familiar with the discussions.

Mr. Blumenthal, the top Democrat on the Commerce Committee’s consumer protection panel, said there was “very powerful support for privacy legislation across party lines because most people don’t regard it in any way as a partisan issue.”

Still, there will be plenty of details for lawmakers to tangle over, in particular the interaction between any new federal legislation and the California state law.

“That’s a big part of this whole discussion—how can we do this in a way that respects the states that do want the strong laws?” said Sen. Ed Markey (D., Mass.), who is working on legislation focused on online privacy protections for children under the age of 16.

Some lawmakers were skeptical that Congress would be able to agree on an approach to privacy guidelines.

“I hope that we’ll pass something, but you know, we’ll see,” said Sen. Josh Hawley (R., Mo.), a freshman lawmaker who has introduced two bipartisan privacy bills of his own since taking office in January. “I don’t know how much enthusiasm there is for that on the Republican side right now,” he said.

Technology companies have warmed to a national privacy law as the implementation of the California law approaches, hoping a federal rule would be less stringent and provide a sole set of guidelines. Supporters of big tech companies have warned against regulation that could threaten competition. in the sector.

Some Democrats have called for taking more forceful action to limit the power of the biggest technology companies. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.), who is running for president, called in March for breaking up some companies, including Amazon.com Inc.,Google and Facebook, saying they have too much power over the economy, and urged regulation of Google and Facebook as utilities.

Mr. McCarthy said he disagreed with the idea of breaking up big tech companies.

“If you break up a company, it does nothing about privacy,” he said. “That’s going to take away innovation.”

Separately, the House Judiciary Committee’s antitrust panel last week opened a bipartisan investigation into tech companies and antitrust laws. The congressional probe comes as the Justice Department prepares to investigate Google, while the Federal Trade Commission plans to focus on the dominance of Facebook. In addition, Apple and Amazon could come under scrutiny.

Photo: Al Drago for The Wall Street Journal

Write to Kristina Peterson at kristina.peterson@wsj.com or Lindsay Wise at lindsay.wise.com

Appeared in the June 21, 2019, print edition as ‘House GOP Leader Backs a Data-Privacy Law.’

urn:contentItem:5Y7P-J151-JCMN-Y05F-00000-00WSJ makes changes on corporate beats2020-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:48:08ZLexisNexisWSJ makes changes on corporate beatsChris Roush

Feb 18, 2020( Talking Biz News: http://www.talkingbiznews.com Delivered by Newstex) Wall Street Journal business editor Jamie Heller sent out the following announcement on Tuesday:Hello,I'm excited to announce more moves and opportunities in Corp.Collin Eaton joins the Houston energy team to cover shale companies. He previously wrote about U.S. energy markets for Reuters, delivering market-moving scoops. Prior to that, he covered energy for the Houston Chronicle, where he won a business reporting award from the TexasAP managing editors for a project on meth use in the oil patch. He also wrote about banking and finance for the Houston Business Journal.

He reports to Miguel Bustillo.Also within the Houston bureau, Chris Matthews takes on coverage of the major oil companies, including Exxon and Chevron. With the Journal for eight years, Chris has covered risk and compliance and law out of New York and more recently shale in Houston. He has been a critical contributor to our coverage over the past year on the limits of shale. He will continue reporting to Miguel.Elizabeth Koh joins the Seoul bureau to cover Samsung and global tech. She joins us from the Miami Herald, where she covered Florida state politics, health care and the occasional hurricane. Her work at the Herald spurred the state's First Lady to push for emergency funds to address mental-health issues following 2018's Hurricane Michael, while her reporting on healthcare lobbying on an assisted living facility prompted a restoration of safeguards. She reports to Tim Martin.Nicole Nguyen is joining us as personal technology columnist. Nicole has been at BuzzFeed News for the past five years covering how technology companies' products and policies affect people's lives. In addition to testing all kinds of gadgetry, Nicole has written about Amazon's reviews ecosystem, prompting inquiries from legislators and consumer advocacy groups. She has covered the many ways data is mishandled and how social media companies are trying to curb outrage and harassment. She will work closely with senior personal technology columnist Joanna Stern and report to Wilson Rothman.Newley Purnell is taking on a new beat in Hong Kong covering tech across Asia with an emphasis on U.S. titans' battles in some of the world's most populous markets. For the last several years, Newley has written from New Delhi about how Apple, Amazon, Uber, WhatsApp and other big tech outfits are targeting the next billion users. He has revealed ways new technology is affecting consumers' lives from India to Indonesia. Newley joined the Journal in 2014 in Singapore and worked in India from 2016 until earlier this year. He reports to Neil Western.Jenny Strasburg is taking up a new beat covering cyber crimes, based in London. She'll cover the new cyber threats that companies, governments and individuals face, working closely with the Journal's technology and intelligence reporters around the world. Jenny joined the Journal shortly before the financial crisis. On our finance team she has covered topics ranging from hedge funds and markets regulation to big banks and sprawling insider-trading schemes. In recent years she has covered Deutsche Bank, bringing readers insights into investigations, executive turmoil and the bank's Russia dealings. She reports to Chip Cummins.Patrick Thomas has joined the Management ...reers bureau to cover business education and the M.B.A. Patrick has spent the last year writing about breaking business and finance news as a real-time reporter and has helped out with larger projects, including our investigation into the pricing and marketing of broadband. He joined the Journal in the summer of 2018 as an intern in the New York Corporate Bureau. He reports to Lynn Cook.In San Francisco, we've had some beat shifts as well, several in place for some time now. Yoree Koh is now covering kids and technology as well as general tech news. Betsy Morris is covering Twitter and disinformation. Deepa Seetharaman has been focusing on tech and politics and policy. Georgia Wells is covering Bytedance and TikTok in partnership with Asia colleagues, as well as Snap and uses and abuses of social media broadly. I'm sure you have seen some of the impactful work they have been doing in these important areas.Meanwhile, we have some openings. In Los Angeles, we are looking for another entertainment reporter[1] to help us cover industry changes sparked by streaming. Our tech bureau is looking for a reporter[2] to cover surveillance and privacy. And I am looking for a deputy[3].If you are interested in joining or moving within Corporate, or know of anyone who might be, please reach out to us!Thanks and best, [ 1]: https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwsj.jobs%2Flos-angeles-ca%2Freporter-entertainment%2FA91FC5D7D40F4951AD5603EA5B5FFBCE%2Fjob%2F%3Futm_campaign%3D.JOBS%2520XML%2520Feed%26vs%3D23%26utm_medium%3D.JOBS%2520Universe%26utm_source%3D.JOBS%2520XML%2520Feed-DE...a=02%7C01%7CChristopher.Roush%40quinnipiac.edu%7C350f7a6b53834289d5dc08d7b4add26f%7C0940985869fb4de9987990db22b52eaf%7C0%7C0%7C637176530962289367...ta=e16l%2FgE2ggqiqtOJHkxoifs%2Bqb4LBkc6FOctU5jFgGE%3D...erved=0 [ 2]:   https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwsj.jobs%2Fsan-francisco-ca%2Fsurveillance-and-privacy-reporter%2F3ED2D1A085A44B50B375E2428197F0F0%2Fjob%2F...a=02%7C01%7CChristopher.Roush%40quinnipiac.edu%7C350f7a6b53834289d5dc08d7b4add26f%7C0940985869fb4de9987990db22b52eaf%7C0%7C0%7C637176530962299359...ta=Uh3ncFMJ8NLGo0ieEY48FdQ1Mhg%2Bc9fKwAtWxrUZsFo%3D...erved=0 [ 3]:   https://nam04.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwsj.jobs%2Fnew-york-ny%2Fdeputy-coverage-chief-corporate%2FCCD59C315BAF416B9041F29729D4109A%2Fjob%2F...a=02%7C01%7CChristopher.Roush%40quinnipiac.edu%7C350f7a6b53834289d5dc08d7b4add26f%7C0940985869fb4de9987990db22b52eaf%7C0%7C0%7C637176530962299359...ta=xi69LYCqyRgL7k6WRGTJpg414KHhI2M8NDlVogexi44%3D...erved=0
